Retrieved 12 July 2012. | manageryears1 = 2007–2008 | managerclubs1 = [[Club de Regatas Vasco da Gama|Vasco da Gama]] | medaltemplates = {{MedalCountry|{{BRA}}}} {{MedalSport | Men's [[Football at the Summer Olympics|Football]]}} {{MedalSilver | [[1988 Summer Olympics|1988 Seoul]] | [[football at the 1988 Summer Olympics|Team Competition]]}} }} '''Romário de Souza Faria''' (born 29 January 1966 in [[Rio de Janeiro, Brazil]]), better known simply as '''Romário''' ({{IPA-pt|ʁoˈmaɾiu}}), is a former footballer who played [[Forward (association football)|striker]], manager and current politician. He helped the [[Brazil national football team|Brazil national team]] win the [[1994 FIFA World Cup]] and was one of the most prolific strikers in the world. He was selected the [[FIFA World Player of the Year]] and won the [[FIFA World Cup awards#Golden Ball|World Cup Golden Ball]] in 1994, chosen as forward on [[FIFA Dream Team]] and named as one of the [[FIFA 100|Top 125 greatest living footballers]] as part of [[FIFA|FIFA's]] 100th anniversary celebration. He is also known as one of very few strikers to surpass the mark of 1,000 goals.[http://www.fifa.com/worldfootball/clubfootball/news/newsid=128880.html "Romário completes a famous 1,000"]. ''[[FIFA|FIFA.com]]''. 21 May 2007. ==Club career== ===Overview=== From very humble origins, Romário was spotted in childhood when playing for [[Olaria Atlético Clube|Olaria]], a small club from the Rio de Janeiro suburb. He was taken to the junior team of [[Club de Regatas Vasco da Gama|Vasco da Gama]] where he won two state leagues (1987/88) and earned his first call-ups to the national team. Romário came to international attention when he became the top scorer at the [[Football at the 1988 Summer Olympics|1988 Olympic football tournament]]. Shortly after he moved to [[PSV Eindhoven]], where he won the [[Eredivisie|Dutch League]] in 1989, 1991 and 1992. Romário moved to Spain's [[FC Barcelona]] for the 1993–1994 season, in which, along with players like [[Hristo Stoichkov]], [[José Mari Bakero]], [[Josep Guardiola]], [[Michael Laudrup]] and [[Ronald Koeman]], he helped the club win the [[Spanish League|League]], while becoming the season's [[Pichichi Trophy|top goalscorer]] with 30 goals in 33 matches. Romário was named [[FIFA World Player of the Year]] in 1994, after being the runner-up in 1993. In 1995 he returned to Brazil to play for [[Clube de Regatas do Flamengo|Flamengo]]. He spent the next year in [[Valencia CF|Valencia]]. In 1998, he missed the [[Football World Cup 1998|World Cup]] and then returned to Flamengo until 1999. He played for Vasco da Gama again in 2000, winning the [[Copa Mercosur|Mercosur Cup]], the [[Campeonato Brasileiro Série A|Brazilian League]], the [[South American Footballer of the Year|South American]] and [[Bola de Ouro|Brazilian Footballer of the Year]] award. From 2002 until 2004 he played for [[Fluminense Football Club|Fluminense]]. On 21 October 2004 he was fired from the club after a conflict with the coach. He then went back to play for the team he started at, Vasco da Gama. In 2005, at nearly 40 years of age, Romário scored 22 goals in the [[Campeonato Brasileiro Série A|Brazilian Championship]], making him the league's top goalscorer. In the beginning of 2006, he joined [[Miami FC]] along with former [[1994 FIFA World Cup]] teammate [[Crizam Cesar de Oliveira Filho|Zinho]]. He helped Miami FC reach their first ever USL First Division Playoffs, scoring 19 league goals in 25 appearances for the team. In the biggest coup of the A-League's short history, Romário was signed by AUFC Board member Mel Patzwald to the Australian [[A-League]] club [[Adelaide United FC]]. He played his first match for [[Adelaide United FC]] on 25 November 2006 against the [[Central Coast Mariners FC]]. After his final game during his short stint on 15 December 2006 he finally scored a goal for Adelaide to end what many considered to be a disappointing spell with the club. In January 2007 he signed a new deal with Vasco da Gama.[http://web.archive.org/web/20070326045154/http://fifaworldcup.yahoo.com/06/en/060131/1/5ysz.html "Romario still going strong at 40"]. ''FIFAworldcup.com''. 1 February 2006. ===Thousandth goal=== On 20 May 2007, Romário scored his 1000th goal, a [[penalty kick]] against [[Sport Recife]], playing for [[Clube de Regatas Vasco da Gama|Vasco da Gama]]. The Brazilian press claimed him as one of few players in professional football history to achieve this, like [[Pelé]] and [[Ferenc Puskás|Puskás]][http://www.sportsnet.ca/soccer/article.jsp?content=20070520_214652_4128 "Romario notches 1,000 goal"]. ''[[Sportsnet.ca]]''. 20 May 2007. The 1000th goal drew much attention from both Brazilian and international press, with the game being stopped for over 20 minutes to allow for celebrations from his fans.[http://edition.cnn.com/2007/SPORT/football/05/21/brazil.romario.reut/index.html "Romario nets 1000th goal of career"]. ''[[CNN|CNN.com]]''. 20 May 2007.[http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/2007/soccer/wires/05/20/2080.ap.la.spt.soc.romario.1000th.goal.2nd.ld.writethru.0522/index.html "Romário converts penalty for 1,000th goal"]. ''[[Sports Illustrated]]''. 20 May 2007.[http://www1.folha.uol.com.br/folha/esporte/ult92u115837.shtml "Imprensa internacional destaca milésimo gol de Romário"] (in Portugese). ''[[Folha Online]]''. 20 May 2007.[http://globoesporte.globo.com/ESP/Home/0,,8168,00.html "Romário 1.000 goals"] (in Portugese). ''[[Globo.com]]''. 20 May 2007. There is some controversy over the validity of the 1000 goals as it claim is somewhat inaccurate, because Romário's research team counted his goals in junior, friendly and non-official games.[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/americas/6472327.stm "Controversy on the road to 1,000"]. ''[[BBC News]]''. 21 May 2007.[http://www.dailymail.co.uk/pages/live/articles/sport/football.html?in_article_id=456552&in_page_id=1779 "Romario writes his own history"]. ''[[Daily Mail]]''. 21 May 2007. [[FIFA]] congratulated Romário on his milestone goal[http://www.fifa.com/worldfootball/clubfootball/news/newsid=128880.html "Romário completes a famous 1,000"]. ''FIFA.com''. 21 May 2007. but stated he is still officially on 929 goals, as 77 came in youth football, with others being scored in friendly matches.[http://www.miamiherald.com/628/story/113860.html "Romario bags 1,000th career goal"]. ''[[Miami Herald]]''. 21 May 2007. In 2008 Romário released a DVD with the best goals of his career totaling 900 goals in the disc.[http://globoesporte.globo.com/Esportes/Noticias/Futebol/0,,MUL713246-9825,00.html "Romário lança DVD e diz que Ronaldo está cheinho, mas vai esvaziar"] (in Portugese). ''Globo.com''. 5 August 2008. ===Player/Manager of Vasco da Gama=== On 24 October 2007, it was announced that Romário would take charge of his first match as the interim manager of [[Club de Regatas Vasco da Gama|Vasco da Gama]] against [[Club América]] of Mexico in the return leg of their [[Copa Sudamericana]] quarter final and he would also participate on the field as a player. Romário, then 41 years of age, replaced Celso Roth as the manager of Vasco da Gama, and also played the match against Club América at the same time. The Vasco da Gama president [[Eurico Miranda]] declared to Globo Online that Romário would be in charge of the team for the match, but it is likely to only be temporarily. On 6 February 2008 Romário objected to Miranda's intervention in team selection, so was dismissed, but remained contracted to Vasco as a player. On 4 December 2007, Romário announced he had tested positive for [[finasteride]] (aka Propecia) after a match against [[Sociedade Esportiva Palmeiras|Palmeiras]] on 28 October. He claims it was in an anti-[[baldness]] treatment; however, the drug is banned as it is a [[masking agent]] for [[anabolic steroid]]s.{{cite web |title=Romario fails doping test, blames hair medicine |url=http://soccernet.espn.go.com/news/story?id=487809&cc=5739&campaign=rss&source=soccernet |work=[[ESPN Soccernet]] |date=5 December 2007 |accessdate=5 December 2007 }} ===Retirement and comeback=== On 5 February 2008, Romário announced his retirement both from playing and coaching, effective at the end of March. This move came somewhat unexpectedly, as fans anticipated that he would retire from playing, but not coaching. He made it clear that he will only concentrate on the [[Confederations Cup]] and helping with the [[2014 World Cup]]. However, on 27 March, Romário denied that he had retired. His contract with Vasco had finished so he is now waiting for proposals from other clubs. It is likely that he will return to play a farewell match, perhaps with [[Club de Regatas Vasco da Gama|Vasco]], [[Clube de Regatas do Flamengo|Flamengo]] or [[America Football Club (RJ)|America (RJ)]] (America is a small club from Rio, which Romário's father, Edevair Faria, supported). Romário announced on 15 April 2008 at his DVD launch that he would retire from the game of football.{{cite web|url=http://fourfourtwo.com/news/southamerica/7456/default.aspx|title=Brazil legend Romario calls time on career|accessdate=15 April 2008|date=15 April 2008|work=[[FourFourTwo]]}}{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/7347993.stm|title=Brazil legend Romario ends career|accessdate=15 April 2008|date=15 April 2008|publisher=[[BBC]]}} He cited his weight as a major factor in his decision to retire from the game. Romário played for many clubs that spanned across five continents for over two decades. He scored 71 goals in 85 appearances for [[Brazil national football team|Brazil]] (including appearances and goals in the Olympics) and claimed to have scored over 1,000 club goals. Romário officially announced his retirement from playing, saying:
"Officially I'm not playing any more. I've stopped," he said. "My time is up. Everything has been a lot of fun."[http://english.aljazeera.net/sport/2008/04/2008615172035382296.html "Brazil's Romario retires"]. ''[[Al Jazeera]]''. 15 April 2008.
In August 2009, Romário announced that he would come out of retirement to play for [[America Football Club (RJ)|America]] from [[Rio de Janeiro]]. He stated that he would play for the club to fulfill his father's wishes.[http://soccernet.espn.go.com/news/story?id=667380&sec=global&cc=3888 "Romario announces comeback"]. ''ESPN Soccernet''. 13 August 2009. On 25 November 2009, Romário made his comeback. Fulfilling his father's wishes, he came on during the 68th minute of the match between America and Artsul, replacing Adriano. Although he didn't score, America was able to come forth with a 2–0 win, which led the club to the title of the Second Division of the Carioca Championship. ==National team== As a member of the [[Brazil national football team|Brazilian national team]], Romário won the silver [[1988 Summer Olympics|Olympic medal in Seoul]] in 1988, scoring seven goals. He was part of the Brazilian squad in the World Cups of [[1990 FIFA World Cup|1990]] and [[1994 FIFA World Cup|1994]]. He scored 71 goals in 85 international matches (includes Olympic matches), being the second highest goalscorer in the history of the Brazilian team; only bettered by Pelé. He was a reserve in the 1990 World Cup, playing only 66 minutes in one match, against [[Scotland national football team|Scotland]]. Brazil were eliminated in round of 16 by their rivals [[Argentina national football team|Argentina]]. ===1994 World Cup=== In 1992, during Romário's successful season at PSV Eindhoven, he was called up to the national team for a friendly match against [[Germany national football team|Germany]] on 16 December 1992 in Porto Alegre – Rio Grande do Sul, Brazil. Coach [[Carlos Alberto Parreira]] left Romário as a reserve, after which he expressed his dissatisfaction, saying he would not have come over from Netherlands if he had known he was not going to play. These declarations caused Parreira to ban Romário from the Brazilian team.[http://www.v-brazil.com/culture/sports/world-cup/1994-United-States.html "Brazil in the 1994 World Cup"]. ''Virtual-Brazil.com''. Retrieved 12 July 2012. Brazil played the first seven matches of the [[1994 FIFA World Cup qualification|1994 World Cup qualification]] without Romário, and suffered their first loss ever in World Cup qualifying against [[Bolivia national football team|Bolivia]]. Journalists and fans called for his return to the team. Brazil had to beat [[Uruguay national football team|Uruguay]] at the [[Estádio do Maracanã|Maracanã Stadium]] to finish first of their group. Before the match against Uruguay, Parreira gave up and called Romário. Brazil won 2–0, with Romário scoring both goals, and qualified to the World Cup. At the [[1994 FIFA World Cup|World Cup finals]], he partnered with [[Bebeto]] in the attack to lead his country to a record fourth World Cup title. He scored five goals in the tournament: one in each of the three first round matches, against [[Russia national football team|Russia]], [[Cameroon national football team|Cameroon]], and [[Sweden national football team|Sweden]]; one against the [[Netherlands national football team|Netherlands]] in quarterfinals; and the game-winning header against [[Sweden national football team|Sweden]] in the semifinals. He also assisted Bebeto in the only goal of the match against the [[United States men's national soccer team|United States]] in the round of 16. He was voted the most outstanding player of the tournament. Although he didn't get on the scoresheet in the final, which ended as a goalless draw, he converted Brazil's second penalty in the shoot-out, which ended in a 3–2 win for Brazil. ===The ''Ro-Ro'' attack=== In the subsequent years, Romário formed, along with fellow Brazilian forward [[Ronaldo]], a feared attacking combo, which was colloquially referred to as the ''Ro-Ro'' duo. They each scored a [[hat-trick]] in a 6–0 win against [[Australia national football team|Australia]] in the [[1997 FIFA Confederations Cup]] final.[http://www.fifa.com/tournaments/archive/tournament=101/edition=3424/matches/match=17489/report.html Match Report]. ''FIFA.com''. Retrieved 12 July 2012. ===1998 and 2002 World Cup absence=== Romário was left out of the [[1998 FIFA World Cup|1998 World Cup]] squad. Medical exams had revealed that he had a muscular injury, and he received intensive treatment leading up to the tournament, but he did not recover completely and was dismissed the day of the deadline for the World Cup squad submissions.[http://www.v-brazil.com/culture/sports/world-cup/1998-France.html "Brazil in the 1998 World Cup"]. ''Virtual-Brazil.com''. Retrieved 12 July 2012. Brazil lost the World Cup final against hosts [[France national football team|France]]. Prior to the [[2002 FIFA World Cup|2002 World Cup]], Romário, aged 36, was in considerably good form while playing for Fluminense, but once again he was left out of the national squad by coach [[Luiz Felipe Scolari]] due to indiscipline. The final incident happened when he decided not to travel with the Brazilian national team to dispute the [[2001 Copa America]] in [[Colombia]]. ===Last game for Brazil=== On 27 April 2005, Romário played his last game with the Brazilian national team in a friendly and celebratory match. He wore the captain's armband and scored the second goal in Brazil's 3–0 win against [[Guatemala national football team|Guatemala]] and finished off with a yellow card. ==Recognition== *[[Johan Cruyff]] defined him as "genius of the goal area".[http://www.huliq.com/17544/Romario-falls-short-in-quest-of-1-000th-goal "Romario falls short in quest of 1,000th goal"]. ''HULIQ.com''. 5 April 2007. *[[Roberto Baggio]] said: "Romário is one of the greatest players of all time. He has good technique and personality. He is a master of art in the penalty area."[http://www.pro-paul.net/baggio/english/prevupdates/200107.html Roberto Baggio's world]. ''Pro-Paul.net''. 2001. ==Footvolley and Beach soccer== Since the 1990s Romário has been a [[Footvolley]] enthusiast, playing with friends in various tournaments. In 2006 he won the VIP Footvolley.net Open in [[Miami Beach]], USA; and was runner-up in the [[Footvolley|2011 Footvolley World Championship]] in [[Rio de Janeiro]]. He also plays [[Beach soccer]] and represented Brazil (won the Bronze medal) at the [[2005 FIFA Beach Soccer World Cup]]. ==Political career== [[File:RomarioCongress.jpg|thumb|Romário in the [[Chamber of Deputies of Brazil]].]] In the [[Brazilian general election, 2010|2010 general election]], Romário was elected to the [[Chamber of Deputies of Brazil|Chamber of Deputies]] on the [[Brazilian Socialist Party]] ticket. He was the sixth most voted candidate for deputy in [[Rio de Janeiro]].[http://www.romario4011.com.br/ "Romário"] (in Portugese). ''Romario4011.com''.[http://oglobo.globo.com/pais/eleicoes2010/mat/2010/10/04/sexto-candidato-deputado-federal-mais-votado-do-rio-romario-rejeita-paralelo-com-tiririca-922703880.asp "Sexto candidato a deputado federal mais votado do Rio, Romário rejeita paralelo com Tiririca"] (in Portugese). ''Globo.com''. 4 October 2010. In the present days, Romário is pushing his political agenda against [[2014 FIFA World Cup]] denouncing the event is immersed in corruption and money laundering.[http://extra.globo.com/esporte/copa-2014/romario-chama-mundial-de-2014-de-copa-da-mentira-alfineta-ronaldo-4614675.html "Romário chama Mundial de 2014 de ‘Copa da mentira’ e alfineta Ronaldo"] (in Portugese). ''Globo.com''. 11 April 2012.[http://oglobo.globo.com/esportes/romario-diz-que-copa-de-2014-sera-maior-roubo-da-historia-4345965 "Romário diz que Copa de 2014 será o 'maior roubo da história'"] (in Portugese). ''Globo.com''. 18 March 2012. He also expressed disagreement with [[Ricardo Teixeira]], [[Jerome Valcke]] and [[Sepp Blatter]].[http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VbBWCamjwSQ "Romário detona Ricardo Teixeira e Jerome Valcke"] (in Portugese). YouTube.com. 8 November 2011. He is one of various others claiming that [[2018 FIFA World Cup]] was "stolen" from [[England]] and sold for [[Russia]], in a part of FIFA 2011 scandal.[http://mtv.uol.com.br/memo/ricardo-teixeira-e-convocado-por-romario-para-esclarecer-denuncia-de-corrupcao "Ricardo Teixeira é convocado por Romário para esclarecer denúncia de corrupção"] (in Portugese).
